p.s: The British Premier Minister Boris Johnson gives a speech on COP26 about the importance to take action now.
He speakes to all the members of COP26 who are Premier Ministers or presendents of their home countries and came together at the climate summit.

He tries to draw a convincing picture of the climatclimate crisis but also gives hope by making use of inclusive language and drawing a picture of the scotishScottish films James Bond so the very importance of taking action against the climate change.
Therefore he also makes use of inclusive language and strong adjectives, some parts of formal and colloquial language to encourage his audience to take action.
Boris Johnson starts his speech by welcoming everybody in a friendly tone (ll. 1f.) and immediately starts to talk about the James Bond films (ll. 2ff.).
He points out that the world is strapped to a doomsday device because of the climate crisis(l. 3) to directly present the danger of climate crisis and to draw picture of it.

This brings the danger to the audience because everyone knows about the James Bond films and that there is never room for a mistake for him because if he does not find a solution for the problem, here to defuse bomb, maybe the holewhole humanity gets killed.
He goes on by comparing the situation with the climate more and points out the role of the COP26 members as James Bond (ll. 4ff.).
Therefore he also makes use of facts like the global raiserise of temperatures (l. 8) and that COP26 has to lie trust on scientists (l. 9).
This introduces to the topic and is the base of his argumentation.
Ongoing he describes the history of the fight against the climate crisis in Copenhagen 2010 (l. 10) and Paris 2015 (l. 11) they realised a problem and came to goals.
He comes to the conclusion that COP26 is the moment to take action and not just talk about the dangers (ll. 12-15).

He arguments in the following that the industrialized countries have the technologietechnology to fight against the crisis and to help the other countries so that the whole world is able to turn climate change around and save the world (l. 16-21).
Therefore he appeals to the duty of the industrialized countries to help the others to move to green technology (ll. 20f).
This is the base for his following argumentation to work together (l. 24) and not only spend money (l. 22) but to help their friends to become independent on coal and things like that (ll. 24-29).
He outlines the example of the UK becoming independent on coal and to become the Saudi Arabia of wind to put reliance on his argument (l. 22f.).
Moreover he appeals to the world of everyone.
He says that money and technology are not the problem but the will of the fellow leaders (l. 31).
He comes to the point everyone is talking about the future in 2050 or 2060 but the action has to be taken now, because he notices the following generations and the young people (under 30) (ll. 34f.).
He arguments by giving the opposite that everyone in the room is over 60 (l. 35).

This shows the discrepance between the initional will of his generation and the duty to not destroy the world for the next generaions because they are mostly affected by the climate change (ll. 35ff.).
For him it is important to turn things around and he points out the negative effects of not taking action now to convince everyone of the urgency to take action now.
The generations will not forgive them and they would enter the posterity with being judged by those children and the next generations for destroying their world (ll. 38-42).
The end of this paragraph he tries to encourage the audience by his argumentation and is optimistic to spread hope that climate change can be turned around (ll. 43f.).

His statement gets clear through his argumentation that they have to take action together and he comes to the conclusion that the world has everything to turn around the climate but they have to pull the trigger now (ll. 45ff.).
At the very end he refers to James Bond and his theory of the beginning again.
He concludes his results by drawing the picture of James Bond.
He personificates the cliamte change as a tickning time bomb and presents the summit as the moment to defuse this bomb (ll. 48-51).
His appeal Yes, it's going to be hard.But yes, we can do it underlines his optimism and his intention to spread hope.
The argumentation is underlined by his use of language and some stylistic devices.

Firstly he tries to the draw the picture of James Bond and repeats the term doomsday device and words that mean the same to pull this figure throughout the whole text (e.g. (l. 17) doomsday device, (l. 17) doomsday device(l. 43) cannot, be the end) to remind everyone of the importance of the topic.

Furthermore he makes use of inclusive language to take everyone to their responsibility and duty to take action and to help other countries to turn the climate change around ((l. 19) we now have a duty, (l. 40) because if we fail, they will not forgive us, (l. 16) And we can).
He also points out the word they (ll. 38-43) for that reason and to put a dramatic affect on the duty for the next generations.
His general use of language is in some parts formal but also colloquial in some moments.
For example in the beginning his language is more colloquial to catch everyoneseveryone's and to introduce the summit.
The more dramatic and important arguments are presented in a more formal language to point out the importance (ll. 22-28).

Besides he tries to show his most important arguments and appeals by using a similiesimile (l. 30: He can... we must... we have...), an enumeration (l. 16: coal, cars, cash and trees) and by repititionsrepetitions and an anaphora (l. 46: We have... We have... We have... We have...).
This encourages the audience to take action and creates hope.
His intention gets clear through his argumentation.
He wants to encourage the audience to take action by drawing the picture of James Bond, pointing out the dangers and demonstrate strength in unity.
All in all one can state that he draws a very convincing and shocking picture which makes clear that there is no time left to take action and to do it now.
Ongoing his argumentation does not only create a shocked atmosphere but also hope through his appeal to the unity.
This encourages the audience to turn the climate change around.
His use of language does not create any other effects but it underlines his argumentation.
His strategic use of colloquial informal language creates a strong atmosphere and encourages the listeners to do something.
My hypothesis gets confirmed through the analysis.
